title: Third Party Libraries
description: A third-party software component is a reusable software component developed to be either freely distributed or sold by an entity other than the original vendor of the development platform.
key-ideas: Third party libraries are standardized or pre-built dependencies for software applications which improve the speed and effiency of software development.
Third Party Libraries are often referred to as dependencies.
Open source libraries have their source code available for review, download, and often modification.
Closed source libraries do not have their source code available for review.
Proprietary libraries mean that the vendor retains all rights and licenses to the library, of which a license to use the library must usually be purchased from the vendor.
Vendor reliability, trustworthiness, and quality should be vetted.
Where available, source code should be inspected, analzyed, and vetted.
Libraries should be tested with manual procedures like code review, and automated processes such as automatic code scanners and fuzzing.
Proper error handling should be vetted for the library.
Performance of the library should be validated.
Signatures of official packages and releases should be validated.
Libraries with complete documentation are generally preferable.
